user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_try_map:
```c
static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
			       struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	size_t pages, page, phys_size;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	metal_phys_addr_t *phys;
	uint8_t *virt;
	void *mem;
	int error;

	size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size);
	pages = size / ps->page_size;

	error = metal_map(fd, 0, size, 1, ps->mmap_flags, &mem);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "failed to mmap shmem %ld,0x%x - %s\n",
			  size, ps->mmap_flags, strerror(-error));
		return error;
	}

	error = mlock(mem, size);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "failed to mlock shmem - %s\n",
			  strerror(errno));
	}

	phys_size = sizeof(*phys) * pages;
	phys = malloc(phys_size);
	if (!phys) {
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	io = malloc(sizeof(*io));
	if (!io) {
		free(phys);
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) {
		phys[0] = 0;
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
		"shmem - failed to get va2pa mapping. use offset as pa.\n");
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, -1, 0, &metal_shmem_io_ops);
	} else {
		for (virt = mem, page = 0; page < pages; page++) {
			size_t offset = page * ps->page_size;

			error = metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]);
			if (error < 0)
				phys[page] = METAL_BAD_OFFSET;
		}
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, ps->page_shift, 0,
			&metal_shmem_io_ops);
	}
	*result = io;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_shmem_try_map:
#define metal_align_up(size, align) metal_align_down((size)+(align)-1,align)
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
#define METAL_BAD_OFFSET ((unsignedlong)-1)
...
static const struct metal_io_ops metal_shmem_io_ops = {
	NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, metal_shmem_io_close, NULL, NULL
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining code fragments were not included because they perform obvious functional actions that affect program behaviour and resource management and so are not prima facie dead code: - size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size); and pages = size / ps->page_size; compute required mapping size and page count and clearly affect behavior. - error = metal_map(...); the mmap and its error handling determine whether memory is mapped; removal would change program behaviour. - The early return when metal_map fails and the final '*result = io; return 0;' are control-flow and API contract operations that clearly affect observable behaviour. - The malloc/free/unmap sequences that follow error conditions (apart from the specific malloc blocks listed above) are necessary for correct resource handling; removing them would leak resources or change program behaviour. - metal_io_init(...) is the intended initialization of the region object; when used it obviously affects behaviour (though the initialization call sites are included in the suspicious fragments above where their context is questionable). The fragments reported above are those that warrant further investigation for possible dead code (for example: logging calls that may be no-ops depending on configuration, the single-element phys initialization when multiple pages exist, the virt-to-phys loop and assignments to METAL_BAD_OFFSET, and the mlock call whose error handling is limited). Other lines were not flagged because they clearly contribute to functional behaviour, resource management, or control flow and thus are unlikely to be dead code.
